thread.title: Sultanate of Oman emerges champion at Bullitt GC32 Racing Tour
thread.title_full: Sultanate of Oman emerges champion at Bullitt GC32 Racing Tour

author: muscatdaily@apexmedia.co.om (Muscat Daily News)
title: Sultanate of Oman emerges champion at Bullitt GC32 Racing Tour
text:
Sultanate of Oman emerges champion at Bullitt GC32 Racing Tour October 05, 2015 
With rain squalls scudding across the sky at up to 42 knots, the final day’s racing was abandoned at Marseille One Design, the concluding event of the Bullitt GC32 Racing Tour 2015 in Marseille, France on Saturday. 
Thanks to some strong performances earlier in the regatta, Alinghi won the contest, while Sultanate of Oman’s third place in Marseille was sufficient to make it the champion of the season, marking a maiden Bullitt GC32 Racing Tour victory for an Oman Sail entry. 
Even if there was no racing, the sailors enjoyed sensational speed runs across La Rade d’Endoume in front of Marseille’s spectacular shoreline. 
The Sultanate of Oman contingent with the winner’s trophy and the Oman flag in Marseille, France on Saturday 
A first timer in GC32, Nathan Outteridge was keen to make the most of his guest appearance at the helm of Sultanate of Oman’s foiling catamaran and was pushing the boat hard while waiting for racing to get underway. 
With regular skipper Leigh McMillan busy with his duties in the Extreme Sailing Series in Istanbul, Oman Sail called up Outteridge to stand in for the final event of the season. 
Outteridge was racing with Iain Percy, Iain Jensen, Kalle Torlen and Luke Parkinson and had never competed in a GC32 event before. 
“We hit 36 knots today,” said the 2012 Olympic champion. “Actually, we were a bit disappointed not to break the 40-knot barrier. The GC32 and the way its foils are configured make it forgiving for high-speed sailing. We were loving it.” 
Percy, another Olympic champion, was on board Sultanate of Oman to call tactics, but on Saturday, he was just enjoying the ride. “That was a lot of fun and we are pleased we managed to help Sultanate of Oman win the Bullitt GC32 Racing Tour this season. It’s been a good learning curve for us and we’ve gained a lot from our time racing the boat here.” 
After the light winds of the previous day, Morgan Larson was steeling himself for battle with Spindrift racing and Sultanate of Oman, both of whom were close enough on points to take the Marseille victory away from the Swiss team on board Alinghi. 
“It’s a pity we didn’t get any racing today, but we learned a lot from watching those boys on Sultanate of Oman blasting around,” said the American, who took a more gentle approach. “A while back, I thought foiling was a bit of a fad, but clearly it’s here to stay. It’s awesome, we’re learning more every day.” 
David Graham, the CEO of Oman Sail, praised the team’s efforts, saying, "We are privileged to work with such driven athletes. Our sailors joined this circuit with one objective - to win - and they knew that achieving their goal wasn't going to be easy, especially with an impressive line-up of experienced competitors. The team has a great leader, depth of knowledge, a determined Omani [in Nasser al Mashari] and some impressive teamwork." 
Results: GC32: 1 Sultanate of Oman (10 pts), 2 Alinghi (11), 3 Spindrift racing (14), 4 ARMIN STROM Sailing Team (20), 5 Team ENGIE (21). 
Marseille One Design: 1 Alinghi (42 pts), 2 Spindrift racing (45), 3 Sultanate of Oman (47), 4 Team ENGIE (57), 5 ARMIN STROM (66). Similar content
